Description: An introduction to the classical Latin language in the context of ancient Roman culture.
A continuation of the introduction to the classical Latin language in the context of ancient Roman culture.
Excerpts from Latin literature with emphasis on translation into English.
Excerpts from Latin literature with emphasis on both prose (e.g., Caesar, Cicero) and poetry (Vergil, Catullus).
Readings in Cicero’s orations and philosophical works, stressing rhetorical techniques. Consideration of Cicero’s role in Roman history and his place in Latin literature.
A study of the Latin text of Vergil’s Aeneid stressing the poetry of the language. Consideration of entire poem and its impact on Latin literature.

Course Name: Variable Title Workshop (1-6)Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in Latin studies. S/U grading. Prerequisite: Departmental special approval.46095 Selected Topics in Latin
Description: Topic announced in the Schedule of Classes.

Course Name: or 36171.46096 Individual Investigation (1-3)Investigation of problems in Latin literature or linguistics. IP grading permissible. Prerequisites: minimum 3 credit hours of coursework at the 40000 level and departmental special approval.46211 Latin Prose Composition
Description: Analysis of prose models; writing of connected Latin prose with attention to the Latin idiom.
Characteristics and history of Latin comedy; readings from Plautus and Terence.
Selections from Tibullus, Propertius and Ovid.
Readings from the poetry of Catullus and Horace, with considerations of the general genre of lyric; a comparison of style and content of the two poets.
Consideration of a major prose author such as Pliny the Younger, Livy, Tacitus or Suetonius; may be repeated when a different author is read.

Course Name: or 36171.46374 Juvenal’s Satires and Martial’s Epigrams
